issues.text: what was the common object of the unlawful assembly and whether the offence of murder was committed in prosecution of the common object or was such an offence as the members of the unlawful assembly knew was likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is as to what was the companymon object of the unlawful assembly and whether the offence of murder was companymitted in prosecution of the companymon object or was such an offence as the members of the unlawful assembly knew was likely to be companymitted in prosecution of the companymon object.

issues.text: whether s. 149 is applicable in this case and would cover the case of all the appellants

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether s. 149 is applicable in this case and would cover the case of all the appellants ?

issues.text: whether the offence committed falls within the first part of s. 149 or it was an offence such as the members of the assembly know to be likely to be committed in prosecution of the common object and falls within the second part

anchor.surface_text: In every case it would be an issue to be determined whether the offence companymitted falls within the first part of s. 149 as explained above or it was an offence such as the members of the assembly know to be likely to be companymitted in prosecution of the companymon object and falls within the second part.

anchor.surface_text: For the appellants it was contended that the High Court was number justified in drawing the inference that other members of the party of the appellants had knowledge of the existence of the pistol.

issues.text: whether penalty of death should have been imposed on Mizaji

anchor.surface_text: For the appellants it was contended that the High Court was not justified in drawing the inference that other members of the party of the appellants had knowledge of the existence of the pistol.

arguments.court_reasoning: There is no doubt that on the evidence the father Tej Singh must have known... the High Court cannot be said to have erroneously inferred as to the knowledge of the rest as to the possession of pistol by Mizaji.

arguments.claim: The common object was to take forcible possession and murder was committed neither in prosecution of the common object nor was it such an offence as the members knew was likely to be committed.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellants that the common object was to take forcible possession and that murder was committed neither in prosecution of the common object of the unlawful assembly nor was it such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n s. 149, Indian Penal Code. That was a case where the members of an unlawful assembly went to take forcible possession of a piece of land. The view o

arguments.court_reasoning: Weapons (spear, pistol, lathis), conduct, threats ('finish all of them') indicate prepared to commit murder in prosecution of common object or knew likely.

arguments.claim: Section 149 is inapplicable as per Queen v. Sabid Ali.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants relied on Queen v. Sabid Ali 1 , and argued that s. 149 was inapplicable. There 1 1873 20 W.R. 5 Cr. the learned Judges constituting the full bench gave differing opinions...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: subject matter of interpretation in the various High Court of India, but every case has to be decided on its own facts. - The first part of the secti

arguments.court_reasoning: Differing opinions noted, but every case decided on own facts; distinguishes by circumstances of weapons, conduct unlike sudden counter-attack in Sabid Ali.

arguments.claim: Conviction under s.302/149 not justified as per Chikkarange Gowda v. State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants also relied on Chikkarange Gowde State of Mysore 2 . In that case there were special circumstances which were sufficient to dispose of it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: State of Mysore  2 . In that case there were special circumstances which were sufficient to dispose of it. The charge was a companyposite one mixing u

arguments.court_reasoning: Special circumstances: composite charge mixing s.34/149, no specific common intention for some, fatal injury acquittal, improper notice; not applicable here.

arguments.claim: The common object was not forcible possession but to quietly take possession in absence of complainants, as appellants believed land was theirs.

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the appellants went to take possession in the absence of the complainants who were in possession and therefore the common object was not to take forcible possession but to quietly take possession of land which the appellants believed was theirs by right.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: companyviction under s. 34. It was next argued that the appellants went to take possession in the absence of the companyplainants who were in possessi

arguments.court_reasoning: Ongoing revenue proceedings, armed with lethal weapons, expected opposition; conduct shows forcible intent.

arguments.claim: Offence not committed in prosecution of common object as party divided into three parts, only Mizaji fired pistol, others did not use weapons and fled.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellants that in these circumstances it cannot be said that the offence was committed in prosecution of the common object of the assembly which was clear from the fact that the party had divided itself into three parts and only Mizaji used his pistol and the other appellants did not use any weapon and just went away.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the pistol from his house and was a member of the party which wanted to take forcible possession of the land which was in possession of the other part

arguments.court_reasoning: All collected together on objection, threatened to 'finish' them before firing; conduct shows prepared at any cost, murder connected to object.

arguments.claim: Penalty of death should not have been imposed on Mizaji as he hesitated to fire until asked by his father.
arguments.court_reasoning: Carried pistol sharing common object, used it; son obeying father not mitigating for death sentence in circumstances.

arguments.claim: Appellants formed unlawful assembly with common object to take forcible possession prepared to cause death if interfered with; murder in prosecution thereof under first part of s.149.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge... found that the appellants formed an unlawful assembly the common object of which was to take forcible possession of the field and to meet every eventuality even to the extent of causing death if they are interfered with...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e forcible possession of the Sukhana field. The High Court also found that in any event the case fell under the second part of s. 149, Indian Penal Co

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed by High Court and this Court based on arms, conduct, threats.

arguments.claim: First part of s.149: offence committed in prosecution of common object if immediately connected, no preconcert needed if shared by all.

anchor.surface_text: The first part of the section means that the offence committed in prosecution of the common object must be one which is committed with a view to accomplish the common object. It is not necessary that there should be a preconcert...

arguments.claim: Second part of s.149: members knew offence likely (more than possibility) from arms and conduct.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the offence committed is not in direct prosecution of the common object of the assembly, it may yet fall under s. 149 if it can be held that the offence was such as the members knew was likely to be committed. The expression 'I know' does not mean a mere possibility...

arguments.claim: Case falls under s.149 covering all appellants; murder immediately connected to common object from collective threats before firing.

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether s. 149 is applicable in this case and would cover the case of all the appellants ? This has to be concluded from the weapons carried and the conduct of the appellants.

arguments.claim: Defence of total denial and death by dacoity is false; prosecution eyewitnesses reliable.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the accused was a total denial of having participated in the occurence and as a matter of fact suggested that Rameshwar was killed in a dacoity which took place at the house of Ram Sarup. The learned Sessions Judge accepted the story of the prosecution...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to take forcible possession of the Sukhana field cannot be doubted. Can it be said in the circumstances of this case that in prosecution of the compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Sessions Judge and High Court accepted prosecution evidence of eyewitnesses and Bateshwar.

holdings.text: There is no doubt that on the evidence the father Tej Singh must have known that the son, Mizaji, had a pistol. And in the circumstances of this case the High Court cannot be said to have erroneously inferred as to the knowledge of the rest as to the possession of pistol by Mizaji.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that on the evidence the father Tej Singh must have known that the son, Mizaji, had a pistol. And in the circumstances of this case the High Court cannot be said to have erroneously inferred as to the knowledge of the rest as to the possession of pistol by Mizaji.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Father's knowledge certain from evidence; for others, reasonable inference from relationship, arms, and circumstances.

holdings.text: That the companynon object of the unlawful assembly was to take forcible possession of the Sukhana field cannot be doubted.

anchor.surface_text: That the companynon object of the unlawful assembly was to take forcible possession of the Sukhana field cannot be doubted. Can it be said in the circumstances of this case that in prosecution of the companynon object the members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to go to the extent of companymitting murder or they knew that it was likely to be companymitted ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed from facts of armed entry to disputed field amid ongoing mutation dispute.

holdings.text: the appellants had gone prepared to companymit murder if necessary in the prosecution of their companynon object of taking forcible possession of the land

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found that the appellants had gone prepared to companymit murder if necessary in the prosecution of their companynon object of taking forcible possession of the land , which it based on the testimony of Matadin and Hansraj who deposed that when the companyplainants party arrived and objected to what the appellants were doing they  the appellants  companylected at once and asked Ram Sarup and his companypanions to go away otherwise they would finish all of them

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inferred from lethal weapons (pistol, spear, lathis), collective gathering on objection, and threats to 'finish all of them'.

holdings.text: in any event the case fell under the second part of s. 149, Indian Penal Code in view of the weapons with which the members of the unlawful assembly were armed and their companyduct which showed the extent to which they were prepared to go to accomplish their companynon object.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also found that in any event the case fell under the second part of s. 149, Indian Penal Code in view of the weapons with which the members of the unlawful assembly were armed and their companyduct which showed the extent to which they were prepared to go to accomplish their companynon object.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Know' means more than possibility; inferred from arms and conduct indicating likelihood of murder.

holdings.text: the first part of the section means that the offence companymitted in prosecution of the companynon object must be one which is companymitted with a view to accomplish the companynon object. It is number necessary that there should be a preconcert in the sense of a meeting of the members of the unlawful assembly as to the companynon object it is enough if it is adopted by all the members and is shared by all of them. In order that the case may fall under the first part the offence companymitted must be companynected immediately with the companynon object of the unlawful assembly of which the accused were members.

anchor.surface_text: The first part of the section means that the offence companymitted in prosecution of the companynon object must be one which is companymitted with a view to accomplish the companynon object. It is number necessary that there should be a preconcert in the sense of a meeting of the members of the unlawful assembly as to the companynon object it is enough if it is adopted by all the members and is shared by all of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offence immediately connected to object; shared object without prior meeting suffices if adopted by all.

holdings.text: Even if the offence companymitted is number in direct prosecution of the companynon object of the assembly, it may yet fall under s. 149 if it can be held that the offence was such as the members knew was likely to be companymitted. The expression I know does number mean a mere possibility, such as might or might number happen.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the offence companymitted is number in direct prosecution of the companynon object of the assembly, it may yet fall under s. 149 if it can be held that the offence was such as the members knew was likely to be companymitted. The expression I know does number mean a mere possibility, such as might or might number happen. For instance, it is a. matter of companynon knowledge that when in a village a body of heavily armed men set out to take a woman by force,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second part applies if knowledge of likelihood beyond mere possibility, inferred from arms and conduct.

holdings.text: the murder must be held to be immediately companynected with the companynon object and therefore the case falls under s. 149, Indian Penal Code and they are all guilty of murder.

anchor.surface_text: From this companyduct it appears that members of the unlawful assembly were prepared to take forcible possession at any companyt and the murder must be held to be immediately companynected with the companynon object and therefore the case falls under s. 149, Indian Penal Code and they are all guilty of murder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Weapons, collective threats immediately before firing show immediate connection to forcible possession object.

holdings.text: In our opinion the companyrts below have rightly imposed the sentence of death on Mizaji. Other appellants being equally guilty under s. 149, Indian Penal Code, have been rightly sentenced to imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: It was then companytended that Mizaji did number want to fire the pistol and was hesitating to do so till be was asked by his father to fire and therefore penalty of death should number have been imposed on him. Mizaji carried the pistol from his house and was a member of the party which wanted to take forcible possession of the land which was in possession of the other party and about which proceedings were going on before the Revenue Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mizaji shared object, carried and used pistol; obedience to father not mitigating in context of premeditation and arms.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 149 IPC inapplicable where members of unlawful assembly take forcible possession of land and murder occurs due to unexpected opposition and counter-attack
precedents.cited_holding: Differing opinions on interpretation of s.149; majority held act not in prosecution of common object but personal responsibility; Couch CJ noted little difference between parts but possible cases only in second part

precedents.case_name: Chikkarange Gowda v. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: Conviction under s.302/149 IPC not justified where charge mixes ss.34/149, common object only to chastise, no finding of knowledge of likely murder, and fatal injury causer acquitted
precedents.cited_holding: No liability under s.34 or s.149 on High Court findings; charge defective lacking notice

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the courts below have rightly imposed the sentence of death on Mizaji. Other appellants being equally guilty under s. 149, Indian Penal Code, have been rightly sentenced to imprisonment for life.

outcome.relief_summary: Lower courts' convictions and sentences confirmed: death sentence on Mizaji upheld, life imprisonment on other appellants upheld under s.302 r/w s.149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It was then companytended that Mizaji did number want to fire the pistol and was hesitating to do so till be was asked by his father to fire and therefore penalty of death should number have been imposed on him. Mizaji carried the pistol from his house and was a member of the party which wanted to take forcible possession of the land which was in possession of the other party and about which proceedings were going on before the Revenue Officer.

In our opinion the courts below have rightly imposed the sentence of death on Mizaji. Other appellants being equally guilty under s. 149, Indian Penal Code, have been rightly sentenced to imprisonment for life.
